Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: A Cross Cultural Comparison Of Risk And Adaptation Strategies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the National Science Foundation, Ms Alicia Odewale will conduct archaeological research to examine the natural and social challenges associated with New World slaves in multiple regions within the New World. In addition to archaeologically investigating the risks plaguing these communities, the researchers will also compare the strategies each enslaved community employed to mitigate both social and natural hazards in their environment. This comparative study uses a mixed methods approach, combining the use of slave narratives and primary accounts with archaeological evidence recovered from the former residential spaces of enslaved peoples living in environmentally distinct regions. This research goes beyond current African Diaspora scholarship to highlight the experiences of enslaved peoples serving the most elite factions of society, as well as uncovering those specific environmental challenges of primary concern to enslaved peoples living within urban insular and rural landlocked regions across the Diaspora, and compares the range of cultural adaptations different enslaved communities used to overcome the challenges they faced. The current project remains relevant for risk prone communities across the globe, as certain marginalized or indigenous cultures continue to be threatened by external forces beyond their control. Investigating the use of different strategies to diminish the effects of external forces in the past will present new directives in how to better protect marginalized peoples in the future.

Alicia Odewale and her team will conduct new archaeological investigations around the Danish West India and Guinea Company Warehouse inside the Christiansted National Historic Site in St. Croix, and compare these newly recovered artifacts to the extensive material already being processed by the Archaeology Department at the Montpelier Plantation Estate in Virginia. The investigators will identify and rank the primary risks of most concern to the enslaved community in each region from first-hand accounts of enslaved peoples in the West Indies and Virginia. Four types of risk sensitive artifact classes including: faunal remains, metal wares, ceramics and trade goods found at each site will then be used to identify the possible cultural responses to those challenges that presented the greatest threats to the enslaved community in each region. The central question of this study asks which of these sites presents a riskier environment for enslaved peoples during the late plantation era. The investigators hypothesize that the social and natural hazards present in the urban Caribbean environment for the royal enslaved laborers in St. Croix will pose a greater threat to the enslaved community than the rural antebellum plantation environment belonging to the presidential enslaved laborers in Virginia. Combining the written words of enslaved peoples with archaeological evidence will create a more informed study of the diversity of experiences that existed across the African Diaspora and provide a more inclusive environment for archaeologists, students and descendant communities to work together.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the support from the National Science Foundation, this project supported new archaeological investigations around the former dwelling spaces of royal enslaved Afro-Caribbeans in Christiansted, St. Croix, and compared that newly recovered material culture to the existing collections recovered from the homes of enslaved peoples at James and Dolley Madison’s Montpelier plantation estate in Virginia. This study was the first of its kind to draw comparisons between the tobacco and sugar industry, conditions of rural and urban enslavement, Danish and American governance, and the social climates of the Caribbean colonies and the antebellum South, while also highlighting the unique experiences of those enslaved laborers serving some of the most elite individuals in society, a former American president and the King of Denmark. This study also developed a new mixed methods approach, pairing archival data with archaeological evidence and risk theory to identify how each community responded to the dangers they faced in their unique environments through time. This comparison allowed the researchers to examine the extent to which each enslaved community in two different regions engaged in specific risk management strategies to survive in their environment.

To identify the primary hazards threatening the enslaved community in each region, a detailed analysis of slave narratives and biographical accounts from Virginia and the West Indies region indicated that the number one concern for enslaved people in the West Indies region was the threat of disease and premature death, while in Virginia the number one concern was being sold away or separated from family and friends. These results are contrary to the widely held belief first posited by John Blassingame, that the risk of physical abuse from the master and being sold away would be the greatest fears for all enslaved peoples (Blassingame 1979; Young 1997, 14). However, this research provides evidence that the concerns of enslaved communities were much more diverse than we previously thought and the challenges they encountered were directly related to their specific regional environment.          

Over the course of this project, a total of seventeen shovel tests and four 1x1 meter units were excavated at the Christiansted National Historic Site in St. Croix (Figure 1). These excavations revealed over 4,000 artifacts and the remains of former historic structures possibly connected to the old perimeter of the Danish West India and Guinea Company Warehouse, where royal enslaved Africans were living. The recovered artifacts from St. Croix were shipped back to the University of Tulsa and were compared to the Montpelier assemblage totaling close to 25,000 artifacts recovered from the South Yard of the plantation estate using the digitized database provided by the Montpelier archaeology department, under the direction of Dr. Matthew Reeves. 

Overall, the results of this investigation did not indicate that one environment posed a significantly higher risk overall to enslaved peoples, but on the contrary, indicated that the hazards threatening each community were region specific. The enslaved African Americans living in the Virginia region were more prone to challenges related to the volatile social environment in Virginia with more frequent outbreaks in war, changes in slave treatment laws, a brutal interstate trade system, and changes in social policy and technology. The enslaved Afro-Caribbeans living in the Danish West Indies region were more prone to challenges related to the volatile natural environment found in the Caribbean region with more frequent outbreaks of disease and natural disasters.

This research has supported the completion and successful defense of one graduate student’s (Dr. Alicia Odewale) dissertation entitled “Living Among Presidents and Kings: Enslaved Africans Coping with Risk in Service to the Elite” on November 7, 2016. The research has also trained dozens of local high school students and four college students in St. Croix through the National Park Service Youth Conservation Corps Program and the NPS-HBCU Internship program. These students received training in survey, excavation and artifact processing, as a result of this research and an ongoing partnership between the National Park Service, the University of Tulsa, and the University of the Virgin Islands. The results of this research have been made available through Proquest, tDAR, the University of Tulsa library, National Park Service library in St. Croix, and the Virgin Islands Community Cultural Center in St. Croix, and the Montpelier Archaeology Department in Virginia. Further outcomes that came from this research include an article published in the Journal of African Diaspora Archaeology and Heritage in March 2017 titled, “In Service to a Danish King: Comparing the Material Culture of Royal Enslaved Afro-Caribbeans and Danish Soldiers at the Christiansted National Historic Site”. Other outcomes of this project were three technical reports that were produced for the National Park Service describing the archaeological work that was done at the Christiansted National Historic Site connected to this research and a database of recovered artifacts in accordance with NPS museum standards.
